title: Will Senator Rob Portman (R-OH) be re-elected this November?
preds: *This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
Also in line with consensus. And incumbents have a 98% chance of victory as well.
Sen. Portman continues  to lead by as many as 16 points. http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html
Portmans's >15 point lead insurmountable in 3 days
Seems to be coasting at this point.

Senator Portman has run a near-flawless campaign in a race that is completely overshadowed by the Presidential race in the State which has resulted in little energy to scrutinize the Senate candidates and create controversy.  In recent years, Ohio tends to support Republicans for statewide office.
High favorables for the incumbent and unwarranted (but effective) attacks of his opponent.

Ted Strickland - another career politician looking for additional pension benefits.   When he was the governor, he presented himself as an avid hunter and pro-2nd amendment.  What a difference being out of office makes.

Overwhelming support from republicans on both fronts: pro and anti Trump. Portman's reluctance to support Trump after that famous tape pleased one side, while Pence's urge for the current senator's re-election convinced the other. Ohio is a largely Republican state, with the electorate predominantly supporting the senator's voting record. I expect no surprises there.

This Oct. 18 article on Cleveland.com, http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/10/rob_portman_keeps_big_lead_in.html, indicates Portman has the election won. Raising my probability estimate to 100 percent Portman wins.
Most recent polls give Portman a clear advantage: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html
It looks like some republicans might not vote this time

Moving down a little based on...
http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/10/things_are_looking_up_for_hill.html
Portman is so far ahead in the polls.

He's run an excellent campaign. Unlike Hillary, his flip flop on the TPP appears to have worked - he even has support of the big unions. The piece in today's WashPost indicates the Democratic party is near conceding at this point:
Polls continue to move toward Portman, his lead is over 10% now in polling averages.  Hard to see him losing at this point.

According to this Oct. 4 Politico article, http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/rob-portman-fundraising-ohio-strickland-229074, Portman continues to raise a robust amount of money to maintain his significant lead over Strickland. I'm increasing my probability estimate Portman will win.
Unless there is a sudden reversal of fortunes, the polls are pretty clear who is going to win.
DT reportedly riding Portman's support in OH.

Normally a Senate election, in a presidential election year, in the ultimate Middle American swing state would be a tossup. This year, though, Portman has gotten the support of some key unions (UMW, Teamsters, IUOE, Fraternal Order of Police) that limit Ted Strickland's ability to mobilize union support. Combine that with Trump's general white working class appeal, which seems to be having more of an impact in Ohio than in neighboring Michigan and Pennsylvania, and Portman has the advantage.

Incumbency and polling are both good reasons to suspect he will win.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate
This is a very smart guy who has run a very smart campaign against a very smart opponent.  Hair Boy will lose Ohio, but ticket-splitting will save Portman.
Portman's got this in the bag http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html

Consensus is at 85% and PredictWise agrees, I don't know what Portman has done but it has improved his chances considerably.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate
Portman has been leading in the polls all summer by significant margins.  I't's over.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Ohio,_2016
There hasn't been a single poll giving Strickland much of a chance recently.
Portman's polling just keeps getting better and better.
Latest poll shows he is way ahead, here is link to Cleveland source http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/09/donald_trump_extends_lead_over.html#incart_2box
Strickland had the lead until the summer. Wonder what happened there. Now Portman consistently polling better.

According to this Sept. 11 article in Washington Post, https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/thanks-to-rubio-and-portman-retaining-senate-majority-remains-within-gop-reach/2016/09/11/0dd0d0a2-7830-11e6-a482-61b767c17607_story.html, Portman is comfortably ahead, according to polls. I'm increasing my probability estimate Portman will win in my home state.

 Ohio – Republican incumbent Rob Portman buries former Gov. Ted Strickland, his
Democratic challenger, 51 – 40 percent. Quinnipiac university poll
The D money is going elsewhere.  Since Clinton will carry Ohio, Rob will need ticket-splitting, but will likely get it.

This Aug. 30 article in the Columbus Dispatch notes that both Repubs and Dems have pulled back on ad spending because it looks like Portman has the race wrapped up ... http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/08/30/democratic-group-begins-canceling-ads-supporting-ted-strickland.html. I'm increasing my probability estimate that Portman will win.
National Dem money being pulled out of strickland campaign. Cleveland PD reports http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/09/national_democrats_pull_more_m.html#incart_river_home

+10 from 61
In two U.S. Senate races, the Republican incumbents seem likely to hold on to their seats. Ohioâ€™s Rob Portman
has a wide lead over former Democratic Governor Ted Strickland (40% to 25%), although 25% of Ohio voters
remain undecided. Portman is viewed much more positively (41% favorable, 35% unfavorable) than Strickland
(26% favorable, 54% unfavorable). In Pennsylvania, incumbent GOP Senator Pat Toomey holds a 7-point lead
(46% to 39%) over Democratic challenger Katie McGinty, with 10% of voters undecided. "
Cleveland Plain Dealer all but admits Strickland is "toast"... http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/09/is_it_too_late_for_ted_strickl.html#incart_river_home
Continuing lead in the polls and higher campaign money increases his odds.
Portman still increasing lead in polls, last at +15%

According to this Aug. 30 Washington Post article, Dems are pulling back on ads for Portman's rival Strickland: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/national-democratic-groups-bailing-on-ohio-senate-race/2016/08/30/68d985b8-6ec4-11e6-993f-73c693a89820_story.html. I'm slightly raising my probability estimate Portman will win.
Dem Senate PAC pulling ads for Strickland: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/ohio-senate-ads-ted-strickland-super-pac-227542
Portman continues to poll well above Trump. Would probably take something major at this point to change the outcome.

If I were Rob I'd be feeling pretty good just now, but polls are tricky where ticket-splitting is involved.  Ohioans split rather a lot compared to others but he could still get swept away, depending on how Hillary does.  I will be jittery about this one until election night, probably.  On the bright side, either of these lads would be an excellent Senator; this is not usual.
Up 5% on Politico article about R edge (for now) in voter registrations in OH, etc.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-portman-idUSKCN10Y0VC
He has so far been successfully dancing around Donald, who will not carry Ohio.  He could still get swept away if it's a tsunami instead of a landslide.  (Sometimes one has to mix metaphors. Sorry.)

Recent poll says Portman is still ahead. Kasich's endorsement will probably help somewhat. This Politico article provides some updates: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/poll-ohio-rob-portman-ted-strickland-227278. I'm slightly raising my probability estimate Portman will win.

+ 5 from 55
'Turning to the U.S. Senate race, the Monmouth University Poll  finds GOP incumbent Rob Portman with a 48% to 40% lead over former Democratic governor Ted Strickland.  Another 4% say they will vote for another candidate and 8% are undecided.  Portman garners more support from his fellow Republicans (88%) than Strickland does from his fellow Democrats (76%).  Independents prefer Portman by 47% to 37%.
Polls consistently showing Portman having a 5+ point lead.
Portman is pulling away with a lead and with Koch brothers money and Kasich support, he has to be favored.
Rob Portman is ahead, I'm behind.  Changing to 70%, based upon recent polls and 538 analysis.
Seems to be polling pretty comfortably http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html
Polls moving clearly in favour of Portman (http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html)

One almost feels sorry for the voters of Ohio.  This is one of those rare contests which is not a nose-holder: Both of these lads are good, competent, honest public servants.  Portman may get swept away in the anti-Trump tsunami, but Ohioans are more likely ticket-splitters than many other folks, so he may squeak by.
Portman, is leading in a challenging election for GOP. The upticket causing much of the issue. I think people like him. And the polls have him up by decent %'s.

He might pull this off, and there is a fair amount of Republican money headed his way to help. However, Ohio will go for Clinton, and people do think kindly of Ted Strickland, so straight-ticket voting could finish him off.  It'll be close.
Up by 9 in latest Quinn. poll.

This Aug. 11 article on Cincinnati public radio, http://wvxu.org/post/poll-portman-holds-substantial-lead-over-strickland-ohios-senate-race-0#stream/0, indicates Portman has attained a significant lead. I'm increasing my probability estimate somewhat that Portman will win.
Latest "polls" show Portman "pulling away"  more than a bounce  http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/08/hillary_clinton_now_leads_dona.html
He's popular, but if people have switched off Trump then there might be a mobilisation problem. The Democrats are not going to have trouble getting out their vote.

Dems are going to go after Portman's private-sector work, according to this article: http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/ohio-democrats-set-take-portmans-private-sector-life Will that resonate with Ohio voters? The race is basically tied, though Portman got some union endorsements which worries Dems. I'm slightly decreasing my probability estimate Portman will win.
(no change) Back to my (partly ignoring polls) scenario.
Media notes this is going to be most costly race in history of Ohia politics.  http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/08/ohios_senate_race_spending_his.html#incart_m-rpt-1

Koch network commitment to focus on individual campaigns donations is a big boost for Portman, and will offset any Obama-Hillary linkage in support of the ex-governor and corporate welfare advocate.  Link here http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-charles-koch-donald-trump-20160731-story.html?ct_digitalads_politics_content-promotion_outbrain_________

Looking at polls (which occured before the conventions), I would be slightly raising the odds. Trying to voodoo out the Trump Turmoil impact, I would drop Portman's chances significantly.  Combined?  Going to a tossup.

Portman is leading by 4 points. He has more money in the kitty than Strickland (not counting the Koch brothers' money to SperPACS).
upping the odds by 2 points

Portman is getting some endorsements from unions in Ohio and Strickland's campaign may be lagging a bit. AP article on Wash Post: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/key-senate-race-in-ohio-showing-increasing-promise-for-gop/2016/08/03/827f3c78-5980-11e6-8b48-0cb344221131_story.html  I'm raising my probability estimate that Portman may win.

Based on recent polling, Rothenberg & Gonzales' analysis, Predictitt, Kasich's help, Koch Bros support, teamsters' endorsement, campaign donations and the comment of Liz, an Ohioan, @ http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/292765
Not surprisingly, Koch brothers have picked Ohio as one of 3 senate races that they will focus on. There will be money to do negative attacks on the Democrat Strickland.

I just read that he has endorsed Trump. Gov Kasich has been wise enough to stay away from Trump. I don't know how Portman gets out of this endorsement now that Trump has put his foot in it with his comments about Khan.

PredictWise gives 39 % to the CommieCrat. This is strange, can't figure out why Good Judgment is producing a wildly different result from another prediction market. Polls also favour Portman. He has even picked up union endorsements and has lots of cash in the bank.

As an Ohio resident, I sense that Portman will be reelected. Strickland was ahead in the polls for awhile, but has fallen in recent weeks. Strickland is a lukewarm campaigner, although popular among many who liked him as governor.
The endorsements Portman has been picking up indicate there is a significant trend in his direction.

I'm significantly raising my probability estimate Portman may win after seeing this Politico article: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/rob-portman-ted-strickland-ohio-unions-226326. This seems to indicate that Strickland is weak among certain groups -- and this might hint at broader weakness with voters.

http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate , currently giving Portman a 61% chance. 
Recent polls are also in Portman's favor, http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html#! , 44.7-40.7

Maintaining 100%.
30 June 2016; "Portman, Brown Secure Commitment for Vote on Miner's Protection Act"
http://www.portman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=53CBFD89-45E7-4C47-9E19-AF3205EA7799
another positive poll for Portman + Teamsters endorsement. Up 3%.
Teamsters shifting from Strickland in prior years to Portman this year looks like a group trying to back a winner. Pretty significant development.

Kaine won't hellp Strickland generate african-american (black) votes in Ohia.  WAPO article is rather blunt about that- link here.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/whats-a-nice-guy-like-sen-tim-kaine-doing-in-a-race-like-this/2016/07/13/f7965652-47a3-11e6-bdb9-701687974517_story.html

Republican Rob Portman -------------------------------------185 .....37.00
Democrat Ted Strickland -------------------------------------164.... 32.80 
http://www.suffolk.edu/documents/SUPRC/7_21_2016_marginals.pdf
Drat - I hate when my forecasts go opposite my heart.  Such is life.

Portman seems to be motivated to run an assertive campaign in light of the close race in my home state of Ohio. This July 16 Associated Press article on the Washington Post website gives some insight on how the Portman team is approaching Ohio voters: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/portmans-ohio-campaign-a-sharp-contrast-to-trumps/2016/07/16/35b442c4-4b4f-11e6-8dac-0c6e4accc5b1_story.html I'm slightly raising my probability estimate that Portman could win in November.
Trump campaign disarray will extend down ballot and make Portman a loser.

I'm going to slightly up my prediction for Portman based on a couple of reasons:
1) New poll showing him ahead (as well as other polls showing Ohio tightening nationally) (http://www.qu.edu/news-and-events/quinnipiac-university-poll/2016-presidential-swing-state-polls/release-detail?ReleaseID=2366). Now the poll has Portman up 7 which is a big jump from any other polling, there's likely a lot of noise in that poll. BUT I do think there's reason to believe Portman is at least a few point ahead.
http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/07/13/portman-gains-ground-senate-race/87049774/ positive new Q-Pac poll for Portman
Trivial change, 50 to 55.  Based upon Rothenberg and Daily Kos being slightly for Portman.  Polls appear to be a tossup.  Anxiously awaiting 528 analysis.

The race between Portman and former Ohio governor Ted Strickland is apparently still a toss-up -- but Portman is worried. How will the influence of Trump and Clinton affect the race? Here's Politico article that provides some insight (with a focus on John Kasich's role): http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/john-kasich-rob-portman-ohio-224941 I'm slightly raising my probability estimate that Portman could win, but I'm still favoring Strickland just a bit.
Portman has pulled ahead very slightly, but too close to call.
Portman is moving up some in the polls.  Still early, though.

Ohio Senator Rob Portman is in a close battle with former Governor Ted Strickland. Ohio is a traditional swing state with President Obama taking the popular vote in the last 2 elections (2008, 2012), while current Governor John Kasich beat Strickland in 2010 and Rob Portman took his seat in the same cycle.
He seems to be slightly ahead http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-ohio-senate-portman-vs-strickland
Rob Portman has raised 18,238,407 and Ted Strickland has raised 5,251,529.  Coupled with my previous comments on 15-17 April.  Maintaining 100%.

George W. Bush will campaign for Portman in Cincinnati, Portman's home area (and my home town), http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/politics/2016/06/27/gop-savior-george-w-bush-coming-cincy/86442986/ In my mind, this could backfire. The repeated statements by both Sanders and Trump that the invasion of Iraq was a very bad mistake has resonated with people, including those who are late coming to this same conclusion. I'm slightly lowering my probability estimate Portman will win against Dem Strickland. Portman's activities regarding trade while in the George W. Bush administration might also come up as an important issue for voters.
Polls imply that Clinton will probably carry Ohio. Both candidates are good. I do not think there will be much ticket splitting.

Following predictwise market probability, increased slightly for fundamentals.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate

http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate
Predictwise gives Portman a 55% chance, whereas the PredictIt market says 44% (Predictwise incorporates "fundamentals" such as the incumbency factor). I continue to take the average of the two, and am consequently down by 3% compared to last month.

Sticking at 50-50.  Polls are about even, The Cook Political Report calls it a draw, and I just read a great rationale here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/256589.  I think that incumbent advantage is about countered by The Donald disaster.  Will be an interesting year.

Trump lost the Ohio primary to Kasich, the least Trump-y of the viable candidates. Trump is currently refusing to pivot for the general, so I see high turnout for Dems and low turnout for GOP, especially in a Kasich-won swing state like Ohio. This is sure to affect down-ballot races, and this would otherwise be a close one. I'm sticking with my low prediction unless the presidential race changes significantly.
Very competitive state.  Depends on the outcome of the presidential election and whether there are significant coattails.  Both candidates are popular in the state.
Senator Portman is beloved in most of the state and his dedication to the state of Ohio is appreciated within his state.

Strickland has slight edge in polls (within margin of error) but seems to be increasing distance. Portman has major edge in fundraising (nearly 5x more cash on hand than Strickland). Ohio, like rest of rust belt, is feeling the economic pain of trade deals and globalization. Ultimately, I believe it'll come down to how Trump effects voter turnout. If he can't get Ohio R's to turnout, Portman is obviously in trouble. If he gets new ones on top of the old ones, Portman wins a nail-biter. Right now, I think it'll be extremely close, but that Portman might squeak it out.

He will lose because the top of the GOP ticket is poison and Portman has embraced Trump. Former Gov Strickland is his opponent and he is an excellent fundraiser. He did lose to Kasich in a GOP sweep in 2010, but he fared respectably.  The Dems will marry Portman to Trump and win.
Incumbents get re-elected 90% of the time and even with his stance on Garland I do not see that hurting him much.

Coal miners PAC backs Portman over Strickland
http://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/national-politics/article81338377.html

By removing voters who have not voted, in three consecutive federal elections, from it's voter roles, the GOP may acquire an advantage.  Dems often skip mid term elections, and the current process will eliminate voters who last voted in the 2008 election year.
http://www.wcpo.com/news/political/reuters-infrequent-ohio-voters-wiped-off-registration-lists-for-skipping-elections
(no change) Portman reportedly might not be going to the R convention. Would that help or hurt him?

Predictwise gives his opponent 42%, which implies he has 58% chances of winning.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate

http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/05/strickland_portman_neck_and_ne.html
Portman against the Garland hearing, while Ohioans in general support a hearing.

Portman may be worried. His name recognition is unusually low for a sitting senator, with 40% or so of Ohioans not knowing who he is or much about him. He's a big fundraiser and has many more millions than his opponent, former governor Strickland. Portman now launching multi-million-dollar ad buys -- but could that backfire? Lots of money, lots of TV ads, etc. may look like he's buying the election. Politico article: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/rob-portman-ohio-ad-buy-223112  I'm lowering my probability estimate Portman will win.
Clinton leading in recent polls at top of ticket in Ohio, but race too close to call

Portman is facing a tough fight against former governor Strickland. Politico article: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/ohio-majority-pac-rob-portman-223339 I'm lowering my probability estimate slightly that he will win. Trump also talked with him about being possible VP pick, though Portman says he's not interested.
(no change) Looks like the momentum toward DT being (more) acceptable (to some) is swinging toward positive. Anyone down ballot that is close to acceptable probably can breath easier.
I don't think their will be much of the feared "Trump" effect, whereby anti-Trump Republicans will vote for the whole Democratic ticket.

Democrats tend to vote consistently down ballot less often than Republicans, which may mitigate the Trump negatives, as Dems may avoid him, especially as Strickland is coming off an aggressive primary, and is an insider in an outsider favoring year.

Last 4 out of 5 incumbents won (80%)
Last Republican senator lost re-election  - Minus 10%
Portman is running against a popular ex-governor - Minus 10%
Portman won in a non-presidential year; now it is a presidential year with higher turn-out - not good for him - Minus 5%
Portman got on Trump wagon early - will get almost all of the Trump votes - Plus 4% 
Net 59%
Current polls are showing an even race: So I am going to average down to 55%

When elected to Congress during the years 1994-2004, he always carried at least 72% of the vote, and when elected to the Senate in 2010, he carried 57% of the vote with all four write in candidates totaling only 4% of the vote, which is why he Democratic Opponent Lee Fisher carried no more than 39% of the vote.  If Eric Deatoin (Constitution Party), Michael Pryce (Independent), Daniel LaBotz (Socialist Party), and & Arthur Sullivan (Write-in Candidate) all chose to stay out of the race altogether, Portman would've received more of a challenge from Lee Fisher (Demorcrat).
Polls show a 1% edge for the opponent. It's within margin of error, but they agree about the direction. I am basically at +1% above consensus.
(no change) Portman planning to spend $15M on ads.

Site consensus is 47%.
PredictIt gives him a 49% chance - https://www.predictit.org/Browse/Group/54/Congress
Predictwise's composite forecast gives him 57% - http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate#Link3

Portman has endorsed Trump, and reportedly may be on Trump's short list for VP. What does this mean for Portman's Senate race? It may raise his status among "Trump Republicans" and help him: http://www.politico.com/blogs/2016-gop-primary-live-updates-and-results/2016/05/rob-portman-no-trump-vice-president-222848 I'm raising my probability estimate Portman will be re-elected.
The Senate race is close in Ohio. Strickland is up slightly in the polling.

Public Policy Poll has race in a tie.  Dated May 2nd.
http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/2015/PPP_Release_OH_50216.pdf
One possible advantage for Portman: Ohio voters have a higher unfavorable opinion of Strickland (44%) than of Portman's performance in office (40%).

Increasing my probability estimate Portman will be reelected. He's the incumbent, so has an advantage. He is fairly prominent and popular in DC and in Republican circles. Former Gov. Strickland might be a strong opponent though.
If Trump taps Kasich as VP running mate the momentum may shift in favor of Portman heading into the real campaign.
He's well funded, but there will get an anti Trump backlash in the general.
Leaving my prediction at 50%, but changing methodology.  Since predicting should be a team sport, here are my thoughts.
Miss read my last poll data -- correcting my estimate.
Reading others posted here and adding turnout volatility (advantage Dems).
Latest poll has Portman up by 1.5%.
PredictIt thinks it's 48; bad year for Republicans--Trump and disunity
Check out the statistics for re-election of incumbents suggested by @alanne at https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/reelect.php

A recent poll of just 813 people with a 3.4% "margin of error" shows Strickland ahead 46-43. But figuring in the margin of error, it could be even. The poll is being buzzed up by a Dem group seeking to take back the senate, based in part on president Obama's "clout" with the electorate. The pro Strickland hype is full of loaded language linking Portman to the Koch Brothers and their "secret" funding methods.  Other polls are suggesting the race is too close to call.  To Portman's  advantage is the recent announcement by a major US automaker that they are plowing $1.3 billion into an existing  auto plan in Northern Ohio.  This will become an ugly race down to the wire, and feature its share of "push polling" that contains rumor and innuendo. Too close to call. Keep following Charlie Cook and Chris Cilizza.
The likely nomination of Trump will hurt all Rep. Senators up for re-election. With a strong candidate in Gov. Strickland, the Dems should be favorites to pick up this seat.
(no change) Cokey Roberts on NPR didn't use the exact phrase "Anyone But (Hillary) Clinton" that I anticipated earlier, but thinks this is now the R strategy to limit the damage and/or win elections.

Strickland lost to Kasich in '10, running well where you'd expect a D to--he swamped Kasich in the cities (narrower in Dayton) and much of Appalachia, but he also eked out leads in a block of counties in the southeast--Hocking, Scioto, Pike, Meigs, around there.  He is jake with the NRA, which helps, and is generally regarded as honest;  Rob is thought to be a bit slick by Ohio standards.  It's going to be a D year in Ohio, most likely, so I'm moving Portman down a few for now. Stay tuned.

Former Ohio governor Ted Strickland may give Portman a run for his money. Ohio, particularly southern Ohio, is very conservative, but Portman has allied himself with some questionable people and activities.
Tough one. Seeing as Trump is likely the GOP nominee, that will hurt down ballot Republicans including Portman.

Incumbent advantage = 80%
Republican turmoil = - 30%
Polls = about even, no change = 0%
Other senator democrat = -5%
Ohio house 14 more republicans = 5%
Historical presidential votes = swing = 0%
= 50%

Senators have a >80% re-election rate; RP appears to poll well, and to have performed well in all of the previous electoral contests he has participated in. TS appears to be popular but has not been in public office for the last 5 years, and Ohio is a redder state now.
Most polls, especially more recent polls, show Portman with a slight lead
this is a toss up right now and neither is popular, but I think at the end of the day a Republican is winning the presidency, so have to think this gives Portman a slight edge.
Strickland is slightly ahead in the polling in Ohio.
Times continue to change in Ohio.  Lots of urban support.

This election polls like a toss-up. Some say Strickland wasn't an especially popular governor, but I couldn't find data to back that up -- he comes out looking good, and he lost a very narrow race to a formidable Republican opponent. I sense that the political mood will lean slightly D, so I'll also lean slightly D. Just following a vague instinct, though.

In the face of so much uncertainty I generally assume that the encumbent will win, and I feel that way in this specific situation, but I can't be overly confident because of the hotly contested nature of Ohio politics and Strickland's appeal to more moderate or conservative Ohioans.

Portman has been a senator from Ohio since 2011 and had experience as a congressman and as the the US Trade Representative and as 35th director of the office of management and budget. He has advocated for several important issues in congress such as the republican's recognition of the legalization of same-sex marriage since 2004 and these social issues could contribute to his re-election.
Strickland is up slightly in the polls, presidential races favor Dem turnout, and a Trump or Cruz nomination is likely to cause some GOP voters to stay home and more Dem voters to go to the polls.
The Republican brand has taken a huge hit from the Presidential primary campaign. Trump or Cruz will bring their house down

(no change) With a possible lack of enthusiasm from some for the likely R presidential candidate, I wonder if Portman might get some boost as a "reasonable R." I would think many in the party would like to feel positive about some part of the election cycle.
This will be tied to who ends up being the Republican nominee for president.
His challenger is the former gov. Of OH, has all the right endorsements by all the right people and has a new breath of economic ideas which OH needs and which might have worked in 2011.

On the basis of the current polling (http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-ohio-senate-portman-vs-strickland), and the fact that I think HC vs DT/TC race, won't be good for Portman, I am going to give it to Strickland. But the fact that Portman is the incumbent (although Ohio has also elected Strickland before) and Ohio will be a key state for the whole of the Republican party and their ammunition (http://www.hattiesburgamerican.com/story/news/politics/2016/04/17/wicker-senate-races/83161964/), it should be close.

Former Democratic governor of Ohio Ted Strickland may give Portman a run for his money. Right now, they are reportedly tied in polls. Ohioans may be ready for a change from the incumbent Portman, a darling of the Republican establishment.

Giving Portman the advantage for now.  Ohio has historically elected the same candidate multiple times, sometimes preferring the GOP, sometimes the Dems. Currently, Portman (R) and Sherrod Brown (D) have the two seats from Ohio.  Portman reportedly collected 9 times the contributions of his opponent in 2010, and has another large lead (13 to 2) in this election cycle.  He had a strong lead in 2016 primary votes, as the GOP pulled more voters than the Dems.  One negative is that the GOP has not won a Senate seat in a year the Dems won the presidency (going back to 1976): 1976 (49.5%),1992 (51%) and 2012 (50.7%), although the winning margins were fairly small. Another may be a fall off in voter turnout for the GOP, once the final candidate is known.  A positive for Porman : Strickland has asked for 5 debates, but, Portman is a GOP favorite in preping candidates in mock debates against upcoming opponents.
Very favorable rating in the southern part of the state should carry him through.

Portman is popular. Portrays himself as a moderate (pro-gay marriage), yet he is conservative enough to get the big donations from conservatives and banks. Strickland is not a great campaigner. Clinton will win Ohio, but there will be many ticket-splitters in fall.

he was a main contributer to the desastrous budgets of Bush II.
Trump will cast a long shadow on all senate republican contenders and Portmans is very very closely associated with the Republican establishement.

As I go through all these GJ questions I ask myself further questions to better understand the subject.  At times I do not post them all because they may be considered “way out there”.   But here is a question I asked myself about the elections this year...  Is it better to be a democrat trying to be more conservative or a republican trying to be more liberal?  I am leaning towards a republican with liberal social views at present.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/208704  We can't ignore social mood.

Citing two sources, @Khalid came to a negative conclusion (48%) .  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/208095
But @Flyn1200 cites issues that matter to Ohioans and came to a strongly positive conclusion  (100%).  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/208400
Until I can do more research and hear from a contact who is an Ohioan (@mekilkenny), I'm going to average the two.

Many Republicans will feel disenfranchised or aghast.....and will stay home. On the other side, the Republican ticket will drive Democratic and Independent voters to the polls that will benefit Democratic ticket.

This one is a very tough call.  Ohio is a very close swing state, and if turnout from Democrats is high, as would be expected with Trump or Cruz as the Republican presidential nominee, it would seem that the Democrats would have a slight advantage.  That said, Portman has some advantage as an incumbent, his approval ratings have been decent, though not great, and he has been very effective at raising money, which may be an indication of strength as a candidate.  I give Portman the slight edge at this point as the incumbent.

Strickland was Governor of Ohio and has a few things he will have to defend for example gun control, school vouchers, and abortion.  Strickland seems more like a blue-dog democrat.  On the other hand Portman the incumbent senator is popular in Ohio he won all but 4 or five counties from the previous campaign.  Portman was recently thanked by the Ohio steel workers for protecting the industry from from foreign influence.  Portman is now fighting to protect over 45K union pensions at the federal level.  This is the story I will be following closely.  Will Portman be able to save these pensions from cuts?  I think he will considering his former federal government positions.

Per huffpo it's 75%, which takes into account number of polls and recency of polling to create probability of an actual lead: http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-ohio-senate-portman-vs-strickland
Predictit market is 58% for the Democrat.

This will be better answered once the presidential and vice presidential nominees are known.  If the Ohio governor is part of the Republican ticket then Portman is in otherwise it might be a at best a 50/50 chance.

Portman is quite a lot less crazy than the general run of his R colleagues, but it's probably going to be a D year in the swing states (also, by the way, in the bebop and r&b states).  I'll need to check with my Ohio people, but for the moment 47% feels good.  Probably not to Rob, though.

More research will be done (by me) to refine my forecast, but for now I am going to start at 45%, this seems to be a democratic year, and I believe Ohio is going to be more firmly in the D electoral vote column, and that means a Strickland win here makes the most sense.
